answers.body_markdown:
If the game is open by both users you can use web-sockets.
Its a tech to keep an open connection between client and server, and the server can manage the game and push messages to the clients by the defined game logic.

[WebSockets Doc][1]


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebSocket

Edit: It can be used to manage multiple users as well since the server has all connections and can distribute the messages as it needs.
answers.title: Update content based on server side data changes

answers.body_markdown:
Tested as EventSource. This approach still requires a loop on the webserver who is checking for changes in a database or session. That's not usable for this problem. And a persistent connection is not acceptable for mobile devices.

I found out that the Push API is not tied to notifications. This is defined by the browser implementation. Currently, chrome requires that each push message generates a notification as firefox has a limit of how many push messages can be received without a notification.

So the solution to my problem is solved as i now send a push message from webserver, invoked by a player who made an action.
 

 1. Player 1 selects a field, sends a POST request to webserver to store
    the action
 2. Webserver sends a push message to other player with a serialized
    object as payload
 3. ServiceWorker of player 2 receives message and parses the payload
 4. Parsed payload contains instructions to update the game
 5. Game of player 2 sends a GET request to webserver and receives the newest data
answers.title: Update content based on server side data changes

    image: docker:stable
    
    services:
      - docker:dind
    
    stages:
      - build
      - test
      
    before_script:
      - apk add --no-cache py-pip python-dev libffi-dev openssl-dev gcc libc-dev make
      - pip install --no-cache-dir docker-compose
      - export REACT_APP_USERS_SERVICE_URL=http://127.0.0.1
    
    compile:
      stage: build
      script:
        - docker-compose up --build -d
      
    
    test:

      script:
        - docker-compose exec users python manage.py test
    
    after_script:
      - docker-compose down

answers.body_markdown:
That is because you are asking regex to guarantee a trailing `B`

Let's break it down:

 - `(AB)?` - try and give me a sequential `AB`
 - `.*` - try and give me zero or more of anything
 - `B` - give me `B` or give me death! `B` **must** be matched so `.*` matches the `A` and `(AB)?` is okay with getting nothing

If your input is `ABB` then `AB` would go to capture group #1

----------

Had you done:

    (A|B)?.*B

then at least `A` would have went to group #1 but `B` is still explicitly matched by the trailing `B`
answers.title: Regex question mark quantifier is not greedy enough

answers.body_markdown:
Regex

    (AB)?.*B

applied to string

    AB

works like this:

1. There MUST be a `B` at the end.
2. Sequence `AB` can appear once, or not at all.
3. If sequence `AB` is considered to appear once, then a final B does not exist. So the regex engine decides that sequence `AB` does not appear at all.
4. `.*` will match `A`
5. `B` will match `B`
answers.title: Regex question mark quantifier is not greedy enough

answers.title: Firebase - different rules for multiple hosting sites within the same Firebase project

answers.body_markdown:
You can only have one set of rules per product per project.  If you have two sites connected to the same project, they will both have the same set of rules applied to their users.

If you need to have different rules for different users, you will have to figure out how to designate roles for your users to determine what sort of access they should have to the database.

If you're using Cloud Firestore as the database, get acquainted with [authentication based rules][1].  Similar documentation for Realtime Database is [here][2].


  [1]: https://firebase.google.com/docs/firestore/security/rules-conditions#authentication
  [2]: https://firebase.google.com/docs/database/security#section-authentication

    let desiredScale = 0.5
    layer.transform = CATransform3DMakeScale(desiredScale, desiredScale, 1)

Imagine you're trying to scale a layer and then later read that scale back out (for example: during an animation that's changing the scale).

    let desiredScale = 0.5
    layer.transform = CATransform3DMakeScale(desiredScale, desiredScale, 1)
    let readScale = layer.value(forKeyPath: "transform.scale") as? Double
    print("scale: \(readScale)") // "scale: 0.6666666"

The scale value read out using `value(forKeyPath:)` will be close but not quite right!

answers.title: what does the lambda expression in orElseThrow substitute?
what does the lambda expression in orElseThrow substitute?

answers.body_markdown:
`orElseThrow` is a method of the `Optional` class having the following signature:

    public <X extends Throwable> T orElseThrow(Supplier<? extends X> exceptionSupplier) throws X

This means the lambda expression you are passing must conform to the `Supplier<? extends X>` functional interface. The `Supplier<T>` functional interface has a single method that accepts no arguments and returns an instance of `T`: `T get()`.

Your lambda expression - `() -> new EmployeeNotFoundException(id)` - matches this functional interface.

This functional interface's `get()` method is used to create the `Throwable` instance that `orElseThrow()` would throw when the `Optional` is empty.

answers.body_markdown:
If you are repeating this search many times, then it would be better to use `HashSet<T>` instead of `List<T>`. Hash-set would allow you to search for an item in almost-zero time.

And this problem is unrelated to your use of dictionary, but the structure used inside of it.

In general, if you are repeating same action many times and want each run to be really fast, it is worth it to invest time in pre-building a structure that is fast to use, but might take few seconds to set up. In your case, you could create a fast lookup structure to quickly check if value in a dictionary contains specific key. And using that lookup structure would not require looping through all of the items.

answers.body_markdown:
By default, regex in python matches the largest possible thing.  Add a `?` to make it take the smallest possible thing:

```
x = re.findall("Surname:.*?[0-9]*\s*of", str)
```

The `*?` matches the smallest possible sequence of zero or more things, whereas `*` matches the largest possible sequence

answers.body_markdown:
You are just querying the database not updating the model

*[isDirty](https://laravel.com/api/4.2/Illuminate/Database/Eloquent/Model.html#method_isDirty)* function works if you wish to know if the *model* or given attribute has been changed since the last sync from the database.
answers.title: Laravel: isDirty() always returns false

answers.body_markdown:
Laravel `isDirty()` function:

When `updateOrCreate` method called then your model data saved. so after call `isDirty()` method always returns false. Because data already saved.

    User::updateOrCreate()

Laravel `updating()` means data collected for an update but not updated you know.


**Use of `idDirty()`**
You might come up with a situation where you want to check if a given Eloquent attribute was changed compared with its original stored value.

If you want to find out if a user was `created` or `updated` you can do the following:

If the user was created:

    $user->wasRecentlyCreated
<br>
If the user was updated and a value was changed:

    $user->wasChanged()

Beware that if nothing was changed it will return false

answers.body_markdown:
There is no **one command** for this.

It is possible to write script to do that with combining those two commands.

Note that using integer based metrics like number of pods can be very misleading as pods can vary in how much space and cpus they consume. You might use up cpus and memory before you reach node pod count capacity.

You can check available resources with command: `kubectl top nodes`

> ### Node capacity[](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/architecture/nodes/#node-capacity)
>
> The capacity of the node (number of cpus and amount of memory) is part
> of the node object. Normally, nodes register themselves and report
> their capacity when creating the node object. If you are doing
> [manual node
> administration](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/architecture/nodes/#manual-node-administration),
> then you need to set node capacity when adding a node.
>
> The Kubernetes scheduler ensures that there are enough resources for
> all the pods on a node. It checks that the sum of the requests of
> containers on the node is no greater than the node capacity. It
> includes all containers started by the kubelet, but not containers
> started directly by the [container
> runtime](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/overview/components/#node-components)
> nor any process running outside of the containers.

P.S.

On Debian the first command had to be slightly modified to work:
```
kubectl describe node | grep -E "(^Name:|^Non-terminated)"
```

answers.body_markdown:
All the `setattr` function does is to assign to the object's `__dict__` dictionary the given value at the given key. It does not do any validation against the key, so you can retrieve the value with `getattr` like this:

    getattr(obj, '@#^&%$&')

which returns the value you assigned to the said key:

    None

The attribute name after the dot notation, however, is not part of a quoted string, and therefore does have to follow the Python naming syntax or the interpreter cannot parse it properly.

answers.body_markdown:
Create a list of the vectors and then use the `sapply` shown.  No packages are used.


    L <- list(one = one, two = two, three = three)

    rnames <- sort(unique(unlist(L)))
    m <- +sapply(L, function(x) rnames %in% x)
    rownames(m) <- rnames

    m

giving:

      one two three
    a   1   0     1
    b   1   1     1
    c   0   0     1
    d   1   0     0
    e   0   1     0
    f   1   0     1

## Variations

The `sapply` line above could be written even more compactly like this:

    m <- +sapply(L, `%in%`, x = rnames)

or we could use `outer`. This also sets the row names:

    m <- + outer(setNames(rnames, rnames), L, Vectorize(`%in%`))
answers.title: Merging diferent vectors into a 0/1 dataframe

answers.body_markdown:
A `tidyverse` approach could be to construct a list of three objects, bring them into one dataframe, `unnest` the values and get the data in wide format using `pivot_wider`.


    library(tidyverse)

    lst(one, two, three) %>%
       enframe() %>%
       unnest(cols = "value") %>%
       mutate(n = 1) %>%
       #spread(name, n, fill = 0) %>% #in earlier version of tidyr
       pivot_wider(names_from = name, 
                  values_from = n, 
                  values_fill = list(n = 0)) %>%
       arrange(value)

answers.body_markdown:
We can use `table` and `stack` from `base R`

    table(stack(mget(c('one', 'two', 'three'))))
    #    ind
    #values one two three
    #     a   1   0     1
    #     b   1   1     1
    #     c   0   0     1
    #     d   1   0     0
    #     e   0   1     0
    #     f   1   0     1

---

Or using `mtabulate` from `qdapTools`

    library(qdapTools)
    t(mtabulate(mget(c("one", "two", "three"))))

answers.body_markdown:
In response to your question in the comments above.  
My approach is to convert the date column into an actual date object with the as.Date function. With that you can then subset/filter/select to the desired time periods (rows) to perform the t.test.
   
    df<-read.table(header = TRUE, text="date        CVDadmissions 
    2001.04.01   22
    2001.04.02   26
    2001.04.03   27
    2002.04.01   22
    2002.04.02   23
    2002.04.03   25
    2003.04.01   27
    2003.04.02   28
    2003.04.03   29
    2003.04.04   30")
    
    
    df$date<-as.Date(df$date, "%Y.%m.%d")
    
    t.test(CVDadmissions ~ format(date, "%Y"), data=df[df$date<as.Date("2003-01-01"),])

    #or 
    t.test(CVDadmissions ~ format(date, "%Y"), data=df[format(df$date, "%Y")=="2001" | format(df$date, "%Y")=="2002",])
answers.title: How to apply t-test for groups by dates in R?

answers.body_markdown:
You shouldn't think in terms of the current URL, but rather in terms of the context of the page. 

This is an author detail view, so you already have an item named `author` - also referenced as `object` - in the template, and you are presumably already using it to display data from the author model, such as `{{ author.name }}` etc. So you can use that to create your link:

    {% url "author_update" pk=author.pk %}

(Note, I don't know why you have defined a `page` method in your AuthorDetailView class. That method will never be called by anything; you should delete it.)

answers.body_markdown: The problematic part is `= group.each do |post|` since `each` returns the array itself as well in addition to running the loop. And since you have an `=` sign before it so the `=` in the `view` would also render the returned output of the `group.each` statement. You may want to use `-` as `- group.each do |post|` as it will render the output of `group.each`.

answers.body_markdown:
You can use `pmin` to set the range between 0 and 1.
```
pmin(table(ds$b,ds$a), 1)
#    a b
#  d 1 0
#  f 1 0
#  g 0 1
```
Or use `unique` before `table`:
```
table(unique(ds)[2:1])
#b   a b
#  d 1 0
#  f 1 0
#  g 0 1
```

Data:
```
ds  <- data.frame(a=c("a","a","b","b"), b=c("f","d","g","g"))
```

Using `tidyverse`

    library(dplyr)

    #  a         f     d     g
    #  <fct> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>

    #2 b         0     0     1
